articles.title: Despite ongoing discrimination, women entrepreneurs are reshaping the Global South, with crucial support from the UN
articles.summary: Exceptional women business leaders such as African engineer-turned-entrepreneur Norah Magero are demonstrating how lived experience and ingenuity, backed by United Nations support, can turn promising ideas into successful companies, even in societies where their voices have long been sidelined.
articles.content:
As a young mother in a remote part of eastern Kenya, Norah Magero struggled to get her child reliable health care. “We faced lots of blackouts, and it was always a race against time to get her vaccinated.”

Safely storing and transporting heat-sensitive medical products like vaccines, blood for transfusion and insulin is a challenge for health clinics in rural areas of the country, where electricity access is often unreliable.

With her engineering background, Ms. Magero decided that this was a problem she could solve. She started her own company, Drop Access, and created Vacci Box, an innovative, solar-powered mobile refrigerator that can be carried on a moped or even by donkey, whilst ensuring the products are chilled to exactly the right temperature.

However, inventing the Vacci Box was just the first step towards helping others in her situation. Through local contacts she came across the UN Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) and was able to access the training she needed in order to become a successful entrepreneur.

UN News/ Conor Lennon Norah Magero, CEO of Kenyan health tech company Drop Access

The future of industry must be inclusive

Today, Drop Access is selling its products in Kenya, Tanzania, Zambia, and Côte d’Ivoire, with ambitions to expand across Africa and Southeast Asia, and Ms. Magero has won a Women in Industry award at this year’s UNIDO Global Industry Summit.

By dedicating a full day to women’s empowerment and their role in the future of industry and the economy, the Summit sent a clear message: the future of industry must be inclusive. A spotlight was shone on the contributions of women innovators, entrepreneurs and policymakers and, at the same time, speakers addressed the barriers that continue to limit their full participation in industry.

“Despite decades of commitments, women remain under-represented in the sectors shaping our future, especially high-tech, digital, and green industries,” said Cecilia Estrada, the UNIDO head of policy, at the opening session of the conference. “Leadership and gender pay gaps persist across manufacturing, energy, and agro-industries. These disparities are as unjust as they are inefficient. They cost us innovation, resilience, and inclusive growth.”

The support UNIDO is making available to women business leaders such as Ms. Magero include entrepreneurship programmes that open access for women to finance markets and technology, and investments in STEM and digital skills for women and girls, preparing them for leadership in the industries of the future.

A breakthrough was made on Tuesday, when UNIDO Member States adopted the Gender Equality and Empowerment of Women in Industrial Development Resolution, aimed at ensuring that gender equality is embedded across all UNIDO operations, programmes and partnerships.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

The story has broad significance for gender equality, economic inclusion, and health access, with substantial context and a clear positive change.

articles.title: Italian parliament unanimously votes to make femicide a crime
articles.summary: The gender-motivated murder of a woman will now be covered by a distinct clause in Italian law - punishable by a life sentence.
articles.content:
Italian parliament unanimously votes to make femicide a crime

4 hours ago Share Save Sarah Rainsford Southern and Eastern Europe correspondent , Rome Share Save

Getty Images A Naples protest following the death of fourteen year-old Martina Carbonaro who was killed by her ex-boyfriend in May 2025

Deputies in the Italian parliament have voted unanimously to introduce the crime of femicide – the murder of a woman, motivated by gender – as a distinct law to be punished with a life sentence. In a symbolic move, the bill was approved on the day dedicated to the elimination of violence against women worldwide. The idea of a law on femicide had been discussed in Italy before but the murder of Giulia Cecchettin by her ex-boyfriend was a tragedy that shocked the country into action. In late November 2022, the 22-year-old was stabbed to death by Filippo Turetta, who then wrapped her body in bags and dumped it by a lakeside.

AFP via Getty Images Thousands gathered outside the church where Giulia Cecchettin's funeral was held to pay their respects

The killing was headline news until he was caught, but it was the powerful response of Giulia's sister, Elena, that has endured. The murderer was not a monster, she said, but the "healthy son" of a deeply patriarchal society. They were words that brought crowds out across Italy demanding change. Two years on, MPs have voted for a law on femicide after a long and passionately debated session of parliament. It makes Italy one of very few places to categorise femicide as a distinct crime. Introduced by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, the law was backed by her own hard-right government, as well as opposition MPs. Many wore red ribbons or red jackets today to remember the victims of violence. From now on, Italy will record every murder of a woman that is motivated by her gender as femicide. "Femicides will be classified, they will be studied in their real context, they will exist," Judge Paola di Nicola, one of the authors of the new law, said of its significance. She was part of an expert commission that examined 211 recent murders of women for common characteristics, then drafted the femicide law. "Talking of such crimes as rooted in exasperated love or strong jealousy is a distortion – that uses romantic, culturally acceptable terms," the judge argues, surrounded by her research at her home in Rome. "This law means we will be the first in Europe to reveal the real motivation of the perpetrators, which is hierarchy and power." Italy will now join Cyprus, Malta and Croatia as EU member states that have introduced a legal definition of femicide in their criminal codes.

Judge Paola di Nicola helped draft the new law on femicide, the first of its kind in Europe

There is no agreed worldwide definition of femicide, which makes it hard to count and compare statistics. The Italian law will apply to murders which are "an act of hatred, discrimination, domination, control, or subjugation of a woman as a woman", or that occur when she breaks off a relationship or to "limit her individual freedoms." The latest police data in Italy shows a slight fall in the number of women killed last year to 116, with 106 said to be motivated by gender. In future, such cases would be recorded separately and trigger an automatic life sentence, meant as a deterrent. Gino Cecchettin isn't sure such a law would have saved his daughter: her killer was sent to prison for life in any case. But he does think defining and discussing the problem is important. "Before, many people especially from the centre and extreme right didn't want to hear the word femicide," Mr Cecchettin told the BBC. "Now this is a world where we can speak about it. That's a little step, but it's a step." His own focus is on education, not legislation. After Giulia's murder, her father describes taking "a very intense look into what was happening around me" then deciding to create a foundation in her name devoted to preventing others suffering as his family have. "I wanted to understand what had come to [Filippo's] mind," Gino Cecchettin explained. "He was a student, a beloved son. Like a normal guy." What he found, he says, was a society full of stereotypes about women and notions of male superiority, and young men struggling to manage their emotions. His daughter's ex-boyfriend had stabbed her to death in a premeditated attack, when she refused to get back together with him.

Protests against violence against women have taken place across Italy recently, often led by feminist group Non Una Di Meno (Not One Less)

Mr Cecchettin now tours Italian schools and universities to talk to young people about Giulia and about respect. "If we give them the right tools to handle their life they will not act as Filippo, they will probably act in a different manner. They will not stick to the model of the Superman, or the Macho Man," is his hope. But getting those 'tools' into schools – in the form of a mandatory course of emotional and sexual education – has not been easy. Far-right MPs have resisted all but optional sex education classes for older children. The Cecchettin Foundation wants them to be obligatory and start early, when young people get access to the internet. The femicide law itself has its critics. When the bill was first presented earlier this year, one group called it a "poisoned meatball". "There is no lack of protection, no legal gap to fill," is how law professor Valeria Torre of Foggia University puts it. She believes the new definition of femicide is too vague and will prove difficult for judges to implement. Also, as most women killed in Italy are murdered by current or former partners, proving that the motive is gender will be challenging. "I am afraid that the government just wants to persuade people it's doing something for the problem," she told the BBC. "What we really need is more economic effort for this problem…to overcome the problems of inequality in Italy." Even those who approve of legislating against femicide agree that it must come with far broader measures against gender inequality.

Museum of the Patriarchy has a temporary exhibit imagining a day when the patriarchy has ended
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legal and societal advancement in Italy by introducing femicide as a distinct crime punishable by life sentence, reflecting a strong stance against gender-based violence. This legal change has broad societal impact, is backed by a unanimous parliamentary vote, and is part of a wider movement to address and reduce violence against women. The article provides detailed context about the law's background, its significance, and ongoing challenges, making it a substantive and meaningful story of progress in human rights.
articles.personality_title: Italy makes femicide a distinct crime with life sentence
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Italy, violence against women has been a serious problem, with many women killed by partners or ex-partners. Until now, these murders were not always treated differently from other crimes.

**What happened** – The Italian parliament voted unanimously to create a new law that defines femicide—the murder of a woman because of her gender—as a special crime. This law, introduced by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, means anyone who kills a woman for reasons like hatred, control, or discrimination can be sentenced to life in prison. The vote took place on the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women.

**Impact** – Italy is now one of the few European countries to officially recognize femicide as a separate crime. This helps the police and courts better record and understand why these crimes happen. It also sends a clear message that violence against women because of their gender will be severely punished. The law was inspired by real cases, like the murder of Giulia Cecchettin, whose death sparked national protests and calls for change.

**What's next step** – The law will start to be applied immediately, with all femicide cases recorded separately. Meanwhile, activists and families affected by femicide, like Giulia’s father, are pushing for education programs in schools to teach young people about respect and emotions. They hope this will prevent future violence. However, some experts say the law alone is not enough and more efforts are needed to address gender inequality.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Italy’s new law officially recognizes femicide as a crime punishable by life imprisonment, marking a clear step toward fighting gender-based violence.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Italie reconnaît le féminicide comme un crime distinct passible de la prison à vie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Italie, la violence contre les femmes est un problème grave, avec de nombreuses femmes tuées par leur partenaire ou ex-partenaire. Jusqu’à présent, ces meurtres n’étaient pas toujours traités différemment des autres crimes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le parlement italien a voté à l’unanimité une nouvelle loi qui définit le féminicide – le meurtre d’une femme en raison de son genre – comme un crime spécial. Cette loi, introduite par la Première ministre Giorgia Meloni, signifie que toute personne qui tue une femme par haine, contrôle ou discrimination peut être condamnée à la prison à vie. Le vote a eu lieu lors de la Journée internationale pour l’élimination de la violence à l’égard des femmes.

**Impact** – L’Italie est maintenant l’un des rares pays européens à reconnaître officiellement le féminicide comme un crime distinct. Cela aide la police et les tribunaux à mieux enregistrer et comprendre les causes de ces crimes. Cela envoie aussi un message clair : la violence contre les femmes en raison de leur genre sera sévèrement punie. La loi s’inspire de cas réels, comme le meurtre de Giulia Cecchettin, dont la mort a déclenché des manifestations nationales et des appels au changement.

**Prochaine étape** – La loi sera appliquée immédiatement, avec tous les cas de féminicide enregistrés séparément. En même temps, des militants et des familles touchées par le féminicide, comme le père de Giulia, poussent à des programmes d’éducation dans les écoles pour enseigner le respect et la gestion des émotions aux jeunes. Ils espèrent ainsi prévenir la violence future. Cependant, certains experts estiment que la loi seule ne suffit pas et qu’il faut davantage d’efforts pour lutter contre les inégalités de genre.

**En une phrase** – La nouvelle loi italienne reconnaît officiellement le féminicide comme un crime passible de la prison à vie, marquant une avancée claire dans la lutte contre la violence basée sur le genre.
articles.personality_title_es: Italia reconoce el feminicidio como un delito distinto con cadena perpetua
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Italia, la violencia contra las mujeres ha sido un problema grave, con muchas mujeres asesinadas por sus parejas o ex parejas. Hasta ahora, estos asesinatos no siempre se trataban de forma diferente a otros crímenes.

**Qué pasó** – El parlamento italiano votó por unanimidad para crear una nueva ley que define el feminicidio—el asesinato de una mujer por su género—como un delito especial. Esta ley, presentada por la primera ministra Giorgia Meloni, significa que quien mate a una mujer por razones como odio, control o discriminación puede ser condenado a cadena perpetua. La votación ocurrió en el Día Internacional para la Eliminación de la Violencia contra la Mujer.

**Impacto** – Italia es ahora uno de los pocos países europeos que reconoce oficialmente el feminicidio como un delito separado. Esto ayuda a la policía y a los tribunales a registrar y entender mejor por qué ocurren estos crímenes. También envía un mensaje claro de que la violencia contra las mujeres por su género será castigada severamente. La ley se inspiró en casos reales, como el asesinato de Giulia Cecchettin, que provocó protestas nacionales y pedidos de cambio.

**Próximo paso** – La ley comenzará a aplicarse de inmediato, registrando cada caso de feminicidio por separado. Mientras tanto, activistas y familiares de víctimas, como el padre de Giulia, están promoviendo programas educativos en las escuelas para enseñar a los jóvenes sobre respeto y manejo de emociones. Esperan así prevenir la violencia futura. Sin embargo, algunos expertos creen que la ley por sí sola no es suficiente y que se necesitan más esfuerzos para abordar la desigualdad de género.

**Una frase clave** – La nueva ley de Italia reconoce oficialmente el feminicidio como un delito con cadena perpetua, marcando un paso importante en la lucha contra la violencia basada en el género.

articles.title: Same-sex marriage must be recognized throughout the EU
articles.summary: Same-sex marriage must be recognized in all EU countries, the EU Court states. Marriages that have been entered into in another country should be able to be registered in the countries where they are not allowed.
articles.content:
Same-sex marriage must be recognized in all EU countries, the EU Court states. Marriages that have been entered into in another country should be able to be registered in the countries where they are not allowed.

Strasbourg – The EU Court has taken a stand in a case that highlights several conservative member states’ views on same-sex marriage.

It concerns a same-sex couple from Poland who previously lived in Germany and also got married there in 2018. When they later wanted to move back to Poland, the authorities there did not recognize them as a married couple.

Now the EU Court has established that Poland must recognize and register the couple’s marriage in some form.

Poland did not want to accept and register the couple’s marriage certificate. The couple appealed the rejection to Poland’s Supreme Administrative Court, which in turn turned to the union’s judicial authority for guidance.

The couple should be able to enjoy the freedom of movement within the union, but the Polish decision also contradicts the “fundamental right to respect for private and family life,” the EU Court announces.

“This is a great victory for love,” says Swedish MEP Emma Wiesner (Center Party) at a press conference in Strasbourg on Tuesday.

A narrow majority of EU member states allow same-sex marriages to be entered there.

(November 25)
articles.reasoning: The EU Court ruling mandates recognition of same-sex marriages across all EU countries, advancing equality and fundamental rights for LGBTQ+ individuals. This decision has broad significance for millions in the EU, promoting freedom of movement and respect for family life. The article provides clear context about the legal case and its implications, marking a meaningful human rights advancement.
articles.personality_title: EU court requires all member states to recognize same-sex marriages
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Some countries in the European Union (EU) do not allow same-sex marriage. This causes problems for couples who get married in one country but move to another where their marriage is not accepted.

**What happened** – The EU Court made a decision about a same-sex couple from Poland. They married in Germany in 2018, where same-sex marriage is allowed. When they moved back to Poland, the Polish government refused to recognize their marriage. After the couple appealed, the EU Court ruled that Poland must register their marriage.

**Impact** – This ruling means all EU countries have to recognize same-sex marriages made anywhere in the EU. It helps protect the rights of LGBTQ+ people and supports their freedom to live and move around the EU without losing legal recognition of their family.

**What's next step** – Countries that do not currently recognize same-sex marriages will need to change their rules to follow this decision. This could lead to more equal treatment of same-sex couples throughout Europe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Court ruled that all member states must recognize same-sex marriages from other EU countries, ensuring equal rights and family recognition across the union.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Cour de l’UE exige la reconnaissance des mariages entre personnes de même sexe dans tous les États membres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Certains pays de l’Union européenne (UE) n’autorisent pas le mariage entre personnes de même sexe. Cela crée des difficultés pour les couples mariés dans un pays mais qui déménagent dans un autre où leur mariage n’est pas reconnu.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Cour de l’UE a rendu une décision concernant un couple homosexuel polonais. Ils se sont mariés en Allemagne en 2018, où le mariage entre personnes de même sexe est autorisé. Quand ils sont retournés en Pologne, le gouvernement polonais a refusé de reconnaître leur mariage. Après leur appel, la Cour de l’UE a ordonné à la Pologne d’enregistrer leur mariage.

**Impact** – Cette décision signifie que tous les pays de l’UE doivent reconnaître les mariages entre personnes de même sexe conclus dans n’importe quel pays de l’UE. Cela protège les droits des personnes LGBTQ+ et soutient leur liberté de vivre et de se déplacer dans l’UE sans perdre la reconnaissance légale de leur famille.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays qui ne reconnaissent pas encore ces mariages devront modifier leurs règles pour respecter cette décision. Cela pourrait conduire à un traitement plus égalitaire des couples de même sexe dans toute l’Europe.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Cour de l’UE a décidé que tous les États membres doivent reconnaître les mariages entre personnes de même sexe conclus dans d’autres pays de l’UE, garantissant l’égalité des droits et la reconnaissance familiale dans l’ensemble de l’Union.
articles.personality_title_es: El tribunal de la UE exige reconocer los matrimonios entre personas del mismo sexo en todos los países miembros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Algunos países de la Unión Europea (UE) no permiten el matrimonio entre personas del mismo sexo. Esto causa problemas para las parejas que se casan en un país pero se mudan a otro donde su matrimonio no es reconocido.

**Qué pasó** – El tribunal de la UE tomó una decisión sobre una pareja del mismo sexo de Polonia. Se casaron en Alemania en 2018, donde el matrimonio igualitario está permitido. Cuando regresaron a Polonia, el gobierno polaco se negó a reconocer su matrimonio. Tras apelar, el tribunal de la UE dictaminó que Polonia debe registrar su matrimonio.

**Impacto** – Esta decisión significa que todos los países de la UE deben reconocer los matrimonios entre personas del mismo sexo realizados en cualquier país de la UE. Esto protege los derechos de las personas LGBTQ+ y apoya su libertad para vivir y moverse por la UE sin perder el reconocimiento legal de su familia.

**Próximo paso** – Los países que aún no reconocen estos matrimonios deberán cambiar sus leyes para cumplir con esta decisión. Esto podría llevar a un trato más igualitario para las parejas del mismo sexo en toda Europa.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El tribunal de la UE dictaminó que todos los estados miembros deben reconocer los matrimonios entre personas del mismo sexo de otros países de la UE, asegurando igualdad de derechos y reconocimiento familiar en toda la unión.

First ever European defence industry programme

MEPs will be joined by Andrius Kubilius for the Commission from 9.00 to debate the new European defence programme informally agreed with the Council. A press conference will take place on Wednesday morning.

Enhanced toy safety

MEPs are set to confirm new toy safety rules to protect children’s health and development. The new regulation extends bans on the most harmful chemicals in toys to endocrine disruptors, forever chemicals and bisphenols. There are also stricter rules on online marketplaces, toy traceability, and customs checks. Confirmation of the second-reading agreement between Parliament and the Member States will be announced at noon.

A safer internet for minors

In a debate with Commissioners Henna Virkkunen and Michael McGrath from around 15.00, MEPs will discuss proposals to make the internet safer for children and tackle rising social media addiction. The recommendations include bans on harmful practices such as addictive design and gambling-like game features and a minimum age of 16 for social media access. The vote on a non-legislative resolution, followed by a press conference, will take place tomorrow.

In brief

Elimination of violence against women

Today is the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. At noon, Parliament will mark it with a statement by President Roberta Metsola followed by statements from each political group.

Simplification of digital regulations. Parliament’s first debate on the “digital omnibus” proposals will start at around 16.00, with Henna Virkkunen for the Commission. The legislative package reviews the EU’s existing artificial intelligence, cybersecurity and data protection framework.

2026 budget. From 13.00, MEPs will be discussing the 2026 budget agreed provisionally last week with Council negotiators, with Commissioner Piotr Serafin and Marie Bjerre, Danish Minister for European Affairs. There will be a press conference with the rapporteurs today at 15.00. Following the vote tomorrow, the President of the European Parliament will sign the 2026 budget into law.

Geopolitical cooperation in the Arctic. In an evening debate, MEPs will assess creeping militarisation, Russia’s military restructuring and China’s interest in the Arctic region, with EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas. They will vote on a non-legislative report tomorrow.

Sudan and Myanmar. MEPs and Commissioner Hadja Lahbib will debate the war and catastrophic humanitarian situation in Sudan from around 14.00, and the political situation in Myanmar from around 20.00.

Votes

At noon, MEPs will also vote, among others, on:

a report on the deteriorating rule of law situation in Hungary;

draft legislation to enhance police cooperation on human trafficking and migrant smuggling;

a request to fast-track a legislative proposal on the bilateral safeguard clause of the EU-Mercosur Partnership Agreement and the EU-Mercosur Interim Trade Agreement for agricultural products;

whether or not to maintain the action before the Court of Justice for the annulment of the decision of the Commission on the withdrawal of the Standard essential patents proposal; and

the appointment of a new German member of the European Court of Auditors.

Live coverage of the plenary session can be found on Parliament’s webstreaming site and on EbS+.

For detailed information on the session, please also see our newsletter.

articles.personality_title: EU parliament advances new safety rules for toys, internet, and human rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Parliament meets to discuss and vote on several important issues, including new safety rules for toys, internet protections for children, and efforts to stop violence against women.

**What happened** – On November 25, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) debated and prepared to vote on new European Union (EU) laws. These include stronger toy safety rules banning harmful chemicals, proposals to make social media safer for children by setting a minimum age of 16, and marking the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women with official statements.

**Impact** – These new rules will help protect children’s health by removing dangerous chemicals from toys and reducing online risks like addiction and harmful content. The focus on violence against women raises awareness and supports efforts to end this serious problem across Europe.

**What's next step** – The Parliament planned to vote on these measures at noon following the debates. After approval, the new toy safety and internet protection rules will become law, and the Parliament will continue monitoring their implementation to improve public safety and rights.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament is taking important steps to protect children and promote human rights with new laws on toy safety, internet use, and violence prevention.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen adopte de nouvelles règles pour la sécurité des jouets, d’Internet et des droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Parlement européen se réunit pour discuter et voter plusieurs questions importantes, notamment de nouvelles règles de sécurité pour les jouets, la protection d’Internet pour les enfants et la lutte contre la violence faite aux femmes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 25 novembre, les députés européens ont débattu et se sont préparés à voter de nouvelles lois de l’Union européenne (UE). Cela comprend des règles plus strictes sur les jouets pour interdire les produits chimiques dangereux, des propositions pour rendre les réseaux sociaux plus sûrs pour les enfants avec un âge minimum de 16 ans, et une journée officielle contre la violence faite aux femmes.

**Impact** – Ces nouvelles règles aideront à protéger la santé des enfants en supprimant les substances nocives des jouets et en réduisant les risques en ligne comme l’addiction et les contenus dangereux. La mise en lumière de la violence contre les femmes soutient les efforts pour mettre fin à ce problème grave en Europe.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Parlement devait voter sur ces mesures à midi après les débats. Une fois adoptées, les nouvelles règles sur la sécurité des jouets et la protection sur Internet deviendront des lois, et le Parlement continuera à suivre leur application pour améliorer la sécurité publique et les droits.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Parlement européen prend des mesures importantes pour protéger les enfants et promouvoir les droits humains grâce à de nouvelles lois sur la sécurité des jouets, l’usage d’Internet et la prévention de la violence.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo avanza en nuevas normas para la seguridad de juguetes, internet y derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Parlamento Europeo se reúne para debatir y votar varias cuestiones importantes, incluyendo nuevas reglas de seguridad para juguetes, protección en internet para menores y la lucha contra la violencia hacia las mujeres.

**Qué pasó** – El 25 de noviembre, los diputados europeos debatieron y se prepararon para votar nuevas leyes de la Unión Europea (UE). Esto incluye reglas más estrictas para prohibir químicos dañinos en juguetes, propuestas para hacer las redes sociales más seguras para niños con una edad mínima de 16 años, y un día oficial para eliminar la violencia contra las mujeres.

**Impacto** – Estas nuevas reglas ayudarán a proteger la salud de los niños al eliminar sustancias peligrosas de los juguetes y reducir riesgos en línea como la adicción y contenidos dañinos. Además, visibilizar la violencia contra las mujeres apoya los esfuerzos para acabar con este grave problema en Europa.

**Próximo paso** – El Parlamento tenía previsto votar estas medidas al mediodía tras los debates. Una vez aprobadas, las nuevas normas sobre seguridad de juguetes y protección en internet se convertirán en ley, y el Parlamento seguirá supervisando su aplicación para mejorar la seguridad pública y los derechos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El Parlamento Europeo está tomando medidas importantes para proteger a los niños y promover los derechos humanos con nuevas leyes sobre seguridad en juguetes, uso de internet y prevención de la violencia.
